investigation.title: Spaceflight Analogue Culture Enhances the Host-Pathogen Interaction Between Salmonella and a 3-D Biomimetic Intestinal Co-Culture Model
investigation.description: Physical forces associated with spaceflight and spaceflight analogue culture regulate a wide range of physiological responses by both bacterial and mammalian cells that can impact infection. However, our mechanistic understanding of how these environments regulate host-pathogen interactions in humans is poorly understood.

project.title: RNA Deep Sequencing and Metabolomic Profiling of Microgravity-Induced Regulation of the Host-Pathogen Interaction: An Integrated Systems Approach
project.funding: Funding for this study was supported by NASA grants NNX13AM01G (C.A.N., J.B., C.M.O., B.J.A.), NNX15AL06G (C.A.N., J.B., C.M.O.) and 80NSSC18K1478 (C.A.N., J.B., C.M.O. and H.B.).

publications.title: Spaceflight Analogue Culture Enhances the Host-Pathogen Interaction Between Salmonella and a 3-D Biomimetic Intestinal Co-Culture Model
authors: Jason Steel and Cheryl A. Nickerson
publications.summary: Spaceflight Analogue Culture Enhances the Host-Pathogen Interaction Between Salmonella and a 3-D Biomimetic Intestinal Co-Culture Model — 10.3389/fcimb.2022.705647

characteristics.Organism: Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium
